bestBHT.bht: Wherever our treasure is, our hearts will be as well. If our treasure is solely centered on earthly possessions and worldly desires, our hearts will be confined to such finite matters. In contrast, if our treasure consists of heavenly riches, our hearts will naturally gravitate towards heavenly pursuits. This principle is expressed in the Bible, intertwining with similar teachings found in other passages. It underscores the significance of aligning our hearts with eternal treasures rather than fleeting earthly ones.

Archibald T. Robertson: Will be (εστα). Last word in the sentence in Luke. Otherwise like Matthew 6:21. See 1 Corinthians 7:32-34 for similar principle.
John Gill: For where your treasure is, there will your heart be also: the heart is always set upon the treasure.
If his treasure is only here, and he has not the true riches, his heart is only earthly and carnal.
If his treasure is heavenly, his heart and conversation will be in heaven.

bhtAttempts.bht: Wherever your treasure is, there your heart will be also. Just as the heart is always set upon the treasure, if our treasure is only earthly and carnal, our hearts will be earthly and carnal as well. However, if our treasure is heavenly, our hearts and conversations will be focused on heavenly things. This principle is emphasized in Luke 12:34, which echoes similar teachings found in Matthew 6:21 and 1 Corinthians 7:32-34.

Wherever our treasure lies, our hearts naturally follow. This truth reveals the deep connection between our desires and the objects of our affection. If we prioritize earthly treasures, our hearts will be fixated on worldly matters. Conversely, when we prioritize heavenly treasures, our hearts and conversations will reflect a heavenly focus. This principle echoes similar teachings found in other parts of the Bible (such as Matthew 6:21 and 1 Corinthians 7:32-34), illustrating the importance of aligning our desires with heavenly treasures.

Wherever our treasure is, our hearts will be as well. The heart is always set upon the treasure we hold dear. If our treasure is solely centered on earthly possessions and worldly desires, our hearts will be confined to such finite matters. In contrast, if our treasure consists of heavenly riches, our hearts will naturally gravitate towards heavenly pursuits. This principle is expressed in Luke 12:34, intertwining with similar teachings found in Matthew 6:21 and 1 Corinthians 7:32-34. It underscores the significance of aligning our hearts with eternal treasures rather than fleeting earthly ones.
